text.p:
Recent advances in semiconductor growth technique have offered the opportunity to fabricate structure
with potential profiles of almost any shape. Closely perfect parabolic effective potential profile has been grown
with this technique. In these structures it is possible to form an approximate homogeneous electron gas within a
three dimensionals space volume that moves in an uniformed distributed background of positive charge. From
the technological point of view, parabolic quantum well (PQW) can be used as polarization insensitive electro
absorptive modulator [1] and far infrared resonant tunneling devices [2]. In this work exciton phenomena on
doped and undoped AlGaAs/GaAs PQWs were investigated by means of photoluminescence (PL)
measurements. The structures were grown by Molecular Beam Epitaxy on (100) GaAs substrates [3]. Fig. 1
shows the low temperature PL spectra for doped and undoped samples with 1000Å well width. We can see that
the spectra are divided by two spectral regions, one dominated by the GaAs bulk emissions (left side) and the
second by the PQW one (right side). We will discuss only PQW emission. On the undoped sample three
emissions are present (named A, B and C). By PL measurements in functions of temperature and power
excitation, corroborated by theoretical calculations, we were able to identify these emissions: emission A is
ascribed to the excitonic emission of 1s exciton on the PQW with bind energy of approximately one meV.
Emission B is associated to fundamental first electron to first heavy hole emission and the emission C to some
excited transitions. For the doped sample, stead of peaks, we observed a large emission related to the
recombination process of the Fermi electron gas formed inside the PQW with photogenerated holes. As can be
seen in the fig.1, an increase on the luminescence intensity occurs (signed by D) near to the end of the PL band.
This enhancement on the PL signal occurs only at low temperature. It rapidly vanishes as the temperature
increases, as can be observed at fig.2. This resonant emission is equivalent to the Mahan exciton on the
absorption process and is associated to scattering processes at the Fermi level.
